bibl.title: Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

body.div1:
(Document Repeated in 0215)
O'eloek we were told by outside officials, much to own disappointment, that the Secretary would not be at his office that day; so I left my card and went away. I called after the next day, and after waiting until after twelve o'clock. I was ushered into the presence of the Secretary whom I found standing up, and he said to me wen on entering the room. "I can only give you a few moments, as the new Spanish Minister is now waiting, by appointment to be conducted over, to be introduced to the President". I then said, "The Secretary then asked once to call again the next day and he told his usher to 'bring one ripher* in", as soon as he got to the office". I called the next day, but the Secretary did not go to his office that day which was a Saturday, and I called the following Monday and Tuesday with the same *sesul that then left Washington, and from Philadephia I had written a letter to Secretary to which was expecting an answer".
They then said that I had not been treated nicely by the Secretary, and that, "If you had a commissioner from one of the Great Powers, the Secretary would have found time to attend to you. The gentlemen, whom I went to see then said to his friend was connected with the Press, and that something ought to be said about N. Heis friend replied."Yes I'll show Blaine up" ! I replied, "I beg that you will do us such thing, as consider that Mr. Blaine treated me very courteous and I consider that he showed me special honor in granting once our interior at all, under all the circumstances, and when so many others had been waiting so much longer than I to get an interview with him" "One of the gentlemen found waiting to see the Secretary told me that he had been visiting the Department for fourteen days consectively, and had mayor been favored with an interview; on of the officials told me that the Secretary was conferring with Delegations from the South American Pl** about commercial treaties that he wished to make with them and if they often went to his residence to confer, and thus caused them to be when from thr Department for several days consentiality. I said I felt quite sure that if the Spanish Minister had not then been waiiting Mr. Blaine would have heard all that I had to say on the subject of my mission. "Here the communication about my visit to Washington ended, the other reason left, and the gentlemen and went on to talk of the matters, about which I had called his office.
From my conversation with those men, judged that they were both, political opponents of yourself and your division that; and when I saw that *artileiu "The World" I at once wrote a letter to the Editor repredmating* the article as being false in every essential statement, and if I were now in the U.S. I think I should endevaur* to bring on action against the Editor for liked in publishing it. I sent that letter to Mr. Rothery of 116 Walnut Street, Philadelphia and have requested him, if "The World" will not publish it, to have it published in some paper of that city, and to see that it be brought to your notice, so that you might see that I have done what I could do to remove any wrong impression that may have been made about you, by this *aporshy misquoting and mistating, what I said, and what I did *** say about yourself.
Enclosed, please find a copy of my official report made to my Government on my arrival home and hope I was aware of the exsistence of that lying article in "The World", which I hope will convince you that I could not have made the false statements which that article represents me as making
With profound respect, I have the honor to be
Sir, Your obident servant Nelley Davis Late Liberian Commpr***
